messages: b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (20:23): tries to find Big Buck Bunny as VLC-compatible 1080p Dirac but fails
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (20:24): http://www.bigbuckbunny.org/index.php/download/ ?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (20:25): I'm intrested in comparing 1080p CPU loads between Dirac, Theora and H.264
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (20:28): is Dirac still interesting once Google does the non-evil thing?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (20:28): I don't know
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (20:32): I still have a hard time seeing how not publishing data can be considered a good thing

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (20:35): I have a hard time understanding the absurdity of painting the HTML WG as an accessibility offender for suggesting publishing recordings of telecons when the telecon mode of communication is inaccessible before you hit the record button, and the HTML WG charter deliberately tries to downplay telecon and telecons are part of the traditional W3C/WAI communication culture
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (20:38): it is indeed total crap
0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (21:02): 467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db: with regard to Google and on2?
0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (21:02): I'm more worried about the shareholder lawsuit
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:02): 0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17: http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html/2009Aug/0764.html
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:03): 0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17: is a shareholder lawsuit in a case like this something that may actually derail things or business as usual in the U.S.?
a2c4ab05de17e28afa6c204f6392cf90 (21:06): They could always just trade the shareholders for GOOG shares.  ^_^
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:07): a2c4ab05de17e28afa6c204f6392cf90: isn't the suit simply about some shareholder wanting more GOOG shares?
0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (21:07): I would assume it's for the purpose of raising the final price
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:08): 0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17: hence, more GOOG shares, since it's a stock swap
a2c4ab05de17e28afa6c204f6392cf90 (21:08): Oh, buh, I'm dumb.  Sorry, wasn't aware that there was an actual lawsuit going on *right now*.
a2c4ab05de17e28afa6c204f6392cf90 (21:09): My impressions is that that sort of thing is business-as-usual here in the US, but it could always blow up.
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (21:10): a2c4ab05de17e28afa6c204f6392cf90 is Tab Atkins?
a2c4ab05de17e28afa6c204f6392cf90 (21:10): yeah
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (21:10): (unless I missed something I haven't seen you here before)
a2c4ab05de17e28afa6c204f6392cf90 (21:10): Yo.  ^_^  I've been sitting around with a different name for a while, but figured it was more productive to use the name I'm known by.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (21:10): Might as well take it all the way
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (21:11): I've been trying to watch the chat more often lately, get a little more involved in WHATWG stuff.

467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (21:26): From that document Adam pointed out about cookie history (see http-state archives): ".3.1 Fixing the Incompatibility. Because the two extant major browsers dis-agreed on how to treat unfamiliar attributes, we were inexorably led to introduce one or more new headers to resolve the problem."
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (21:26): I'm glad we're no longer doing that now and whenever someone proposes it we oppose it
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (21:26): I hope one day someone writes a paper on writing "modern" standards...
0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (21:28): I've read that transcript bit
0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (21:28): I find the whole argument to be utterly bizarre

0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (21:29): the choice is between making no data available, and making data available so that third-parties, if they so choose, can transcribe, and have 100% accuracy on what is being said
0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (21:29): and some would prefer to see zero-data available
0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (21:30): please tell me I misread these people

467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (21:34): another interesting quote from that document: "RFC 2965, HTTP State Management Mechanism, took 5 1/2 years to become a Proposed Standard, and yet the major vendors largely ignore it"

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:42): interestingly, this guy doesn't focus on HTML5 and MPEG-LA issues: http://seekingalpha.com/article/154160-google-on2-deal-debunking-myths-questioning-vp8-s-quality
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:55): what's a "four-screen strategy? desktop, phone, TV, ???
69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537 (21:56): TV, desktop, laptop, phone
69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537 (21:56): it's some marketing BS from some mobile phone company or other
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:57): hmmkay. What's the point of counting desktop and laptop as distinct?
69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537 (21:58): mobility, leading up to the main point of our glorious cell-phone-enhanced future
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:10): Settlers' II is damned addictive.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:14): Isn't that like 15 years old?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:14): remembers playing it like 15 years ago
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:15): Hell, I'm still sort of addicted to Civ 2.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:15): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Yes
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:15): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: Likewise.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:15): got both of them back in '97 or so
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:16): (Civ2 is probably my number one reason for booting Windows)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:16): (And it saddens me it is 16-bit and doesn't run natively on 64-bit Windows)
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:16): Heh, just virtualize it.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:17): You can run that thing on W95
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:17): Win 3.1, too, IIRC
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:17): S2 runs in DOSBox fine :P
69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537 (22:18): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: I just remembered, it's actually cinema, TV, PC, phone
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:18): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: Find a copy of Master of Magic.  DOSBoxes wonderfully, and it's a *great* game.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:19): wonders if he really needs more timewasters
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:20): 69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537: oh, I see. what codecs do digital cinema systems use?
69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537 (22:21): the over-the-top Nokia marketing video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5V-2qQS3NY0
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:21): likes http://www.gog.com/ since their installer automatically includes stuff like DOSBox to make things work
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:22): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: My diary's already, uh, three months and a half months behind
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:22): Simple solution: cut it loose!

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:26): 69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537: i can see what nokia's marketing speak means, but codec strategy-wise, the cinema case seems different from the cases where the decoder is shipped to the viewer rather than to a theater
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:26): Agreed - I'm not sure how the two necessarily have to be related.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:27): maybe my strategy mindset isn't broad enough
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:31): contemplates what to do
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:36): btw, why do people seem to assume that purchasing transcripts is an issue?

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:37): if the W3C has a policy requiring transripts, surely it would be sensible for the W3C to already have a mechanism for sending audio to a service provider and getting text back
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:37): does the policy exist withou such a mechanism in place? what's the issue here?
